subject: Re: Order #SSN1981, how did it go?
description_text:
Honestly they are garbage. I have 2 sets that do exactly the same thing.
Both on brand new pro x pedals.

Issue.
- your 24v power supply connector does not even fit into your network box.
It is extremely loose.
- while racing you can feel it hit a frequency and just stay there. Even if
you shut off the sim and more importantly if you shut down your software.
- when you unplug the power the shaker obviously stops. However when you
plug it back in there is a large spark and they go back to shaking.
- usb disconnected it continues to shake. So it’s not a signal coming from
the computer.
- it now constantly kicks out the “upgrade” switch and the pedals can not
be used until I climb behind my rig and push the button back in then cycle
power thru usb.

All of these issues started once the shakers were installed. Gas to 1.
Brake to 2.

At this time I have them unplugged as I am ready to throw them against the
wall. The box is not on the rig so it’s not a box vibration issue.  I
either need a fix for this asap or I would like a refund for both sets I
bought.



On Thu, Jul 24, 2025 at 9:14 PM SIMSONN <no-reply@loox.io> wrote:

> Hello Anthony, We would be grateful if you shared how things look and
> feel. Your review helps us and the community that supports us, and it only
> takes a few

conversations.body_text: Hi Warped Media,    First, please confirm from your picture that the SIMSONN Manager version is 2.0.9, and the firmware version is either 2.0.3 or 2.0.2, which is normal.  1st issue: The 24V power supply is manufactured by the power supplier. We recommend securing the power connector with a cable tie to prevent it from loosening due to rig movement.  2nd issue: Please ensure the firmware is updated to the latest version and that the USB cable is connected directly to the rear blue USB 3.0 port on your PC. Avoid using unpowered USB hubs, as insufficient power can cause frequent disconnections.  3rd issue: A spark when plugging in the power is normal. Even brands like Simagic experience this; it will not damage the device.  4th issue: This is similar to issue #2, mainly caused by unstable power supply or EMI interference from the wheelbase.  5th issue: The upgrade switch being triggered usually means the control box is not securely fixed or is being accidentally touched. Please ensure the control box is secured; this is a usage issue, not a design flaw.  Our devices themselves have no inherent quality problems. Most of these issues are caused by EMI interference and unreliable grounding in the home environment. I will also provide EMI troubleshooting recommendations because, in our testing environment, VAM Pro can run stably for days without stopping due to USB disconnection.       To address EMI (Electromagnetic Interference) issues, please follow the steps below to improve device stability and USB connection reliability:     1.    Ensure proper grounding: Make sure the computer is connected to a three-prong outlet with a reliable ground. Two-prong plugs do not provide grounding.     2.    Control box grounding: Use a green shielding wire to connect the metal housing (such as a copper post or screw) of the control box to any metal screw on the pedal. Ensure the contact point is paint-free and conductive.     3.    Base grounding (e.g., Fanatec / MOZA): It’s recommended to connect the metal part of the base to the PC chassis or an external ground to discharge static buildup.     4.    Avoid high-interference zones: Keep USB cables away from high-voltage power lines or adapters; route cables separately where possible.     5.    Use direct USB connection: Connect devices directly to a rear USB 3.0 port on the PC instead of using unpowered or low-quality USB hubs.     6.    Use USB cables with ferrite cores: If needed, switch to high-quality USB cables with ferrite beads to reduce high-frequency interference.     7.    Keep software and firmware updated: Ensure SIMSONN Manager and firmware are updated to the latest version, as some updates include EMI handling improvements.     8.    Use a USB isolator: If the above methods don’t resolve the issue, using a USB isolator is recommended. It physically separates the USB power and data lines, effectively shielding the control device from EMI sources.          https://github.com/SHWotever/SimHub/wiki/USB-Issues-Troubleshooting     https://support.gomezsimindustries.com/portal/en/kb/articles/understanding-emi-and-grounding

Maybe you didn’t read my email where I said the box is not physically on
the rig. I also stated that the usb was disconnected during
troubleshooting. Once the oscillators start, I disconnected everything
including usb and network cables. So only power is connected.

As for software, I have on there what your website said to download. But I
will check again.

As for usb connection. That’s not an issue as I already attempted to
connect it directly to the pc and it’s the same as my powered remote usb.

There should be no reason these things are oscillating when there is no
usb, not software connected or running. If you’re telling me it’s a
grounding issue, than that’s yours also. Because I am using what you
provided.

As for the spark. That is NOT normal. That’s only happening because there
is something trapped in the box or the shakers, which is causing a load of
inrush current. I am not a kid. I work with electronics for a living.

On Fri, Jul 25, 2025 at 10:51 PM service@simsonn.com

Hi Warped Media,    I am a hardware engineer. The circuit design requires charging three capacitors for the motor control, which causes a spark during the initial charging moment. The voltage is only 24V, and our device follows the same design principle as Simagic. Even if we send you a replacement, the same phenomenon will occur,

Hi Warped Media,    All of our devices undergo rigorous testing before leaving the factory to ensure there are no issues. Any abnormal behavior is typically due to incomplete grounding or varying interference environments at the customer’s location. Our devices are CE EMI certified and do not emit interference to other equipment. The issue is most likely caused by interference from your base unit affecting our pedal system.

Hi Warped Media,    The interference originates from the powered-on base unit, and it is necessary to follow our recommendations to identify and eliminate external interference. This is not an issue with our device itself. Our products have been thoroughly tested, including long-term telemetry testing by an Australian iRacing champion, which confirmed that the USB connection remains stable for several consecutive days. Frequent disconnections can only be caused by external interference, as the device itself is capable of maintaining a stable connection.

I See attached picture. The video will not attach but it’s both shakers
vibrating at a nice 22hz. As you can see I am on your latest software. I
even went as far as separating everything from the rest of the rig. The box
is not touching anything. The cables are not spooled or near anything. The
usb cable is connected directly into the computer (even though it’s got its
own power supply to feed the motors). Also anytime I remove both power and
USB the setting revert back to stock settings.

It appears when it hits a certain freq it locks it in the box. The ONLY way
to stop it is removing both power and usb. The “upgrade” switch also pops
out. This locks out the entire box until I move everything out of the way
to go access it and reset. This is not satisfactory.

So there is apparently an issue with the comms box. Which is not a couple
of months old that I also ordered from you. There is no vibration on the
floor so that’s not an option. These have not worked one time correctly
thru my many attempts at troubleshooting.

On Sat, Jul 26, 2025 at 6:22 AM Warped Media <warpedmedia78@gmail.com>
wrote:

> Maybe you didn’t read my email where I said the box is not physically on
> the rig. I also stated that the usb was disconnected during
> troubleshooting. Once the oscillators start, I disconnected everything
> including usb and network cables. So only power is connected.
>
> As for software, I have on there what your website said to download. But I
> will check again.
>
> As for usb connection. That’s not an issue as I already attempted to
> connect it directly to the pc and it’s the same as my powered remote usb.
>
> There should be no reason these things are oscillating when there is no
> usb, not software connected or running. If you’re telling me it’s a
> grounding issue, than that’s yours also. Because I am using what you
> provided.
>
> As for the spark. That is NOT normal. That’s only happening because there
> is something trapped in the box or the shakers, which is causing a load of
> inrush current. I am not a kid. I work with electronics for a living.
>
> On Fri, Jul 25, 2025 at 10:51 PM service@simsonn.com

Hi Warped Media,  Are you using two ProX devices? Do you have ProX Ultra pedals? We can send you a brand-new ProX Ultra control box to check whether the issue is related to the control box itself. This kind of repeatedly unresolved problem is something we have never seen before, as other customers using ProX pedals and VAM Pro have not experienced anything this complex. If your wheelbase and other devices are turned off, we will send you a replacement control box so you can test and see if it resolves the issue.
